subject: Hurrah for Miss USA
event:
Gotta love the new Miss USA:

http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20110620/ap_on_en_ot/us_miss_usa

Not only is she is a self-proclaimed "history geek" and GAME OF THRONES fan, but she was one of only two finalists in the contest to come out for teaching evolution in public schools.

sigh

Just goes to show.  Fantasy fans and history geeks are much smarter than your average beauty pagaent contestant.

comments.article:
There was some news blurb about her winning on TV the day after that I was only half listening to. I caught "blah, blah, blah Game of Thrones blah, blah, blah..."

After THAT got my attention, I read up on her and was quite impressed. Plus, she's from my home state. I likes her!
She needs to have a talk with the NY Times reviewer who insisted that women wouldn't watch Game of Thrones. There's no icon more feminine than Miss America.
Sigh.  Watching The Tudors does not qualify as studying history.
No, it doesn't, but maybe that's what the trips to Barnes and Noble are for?
Being one out of only two finalists to favor teaching evolution in schools depresses me more than it should. :( Still, good for her!
comments.subject: One Out of Only Two?

comments.article:
Yeah, that made me happy :)

The backlash of "she's too hot to be a geek!!!" did not.
She's a keeper.
It's possible, since amazon.de (the German amazon) mistakenly sent some out yesterday. Did you order it there?
comments.subject: Re: a dance with dragons

comments.article:
Cool!
I read a twit from Eva Longoria who is also a fan of the show!

comments.upictitle: Saithkar - Minister For Apocalyptic Affairs: Noble Goat
comments.article: Good news, although it still says something about America when a beauty pagent winner is prepared to stand up for the truth of evolution yet none of the Republican candidates for president (as far as I've heard) have done likewise. They either don't accept evolution as a fact, or do but are too cowardly to admit it.

The mere fact that there is a public debate about that subject in a country like the US that is supposedly advanced is mind-boggling to me. Here, we were taught about global warming in school more than fifteen years ago, and evolution was of course part of the curriculum - and there was no criticism whatsoever about the teaching of either. If a major political candidate came out here declaring they "didn't believe in evolution", that would be the instant end of their political career, and that includes conservatives.

The only thing that created a bit of excitement in our school was sex education, but that was because one teacher told his class "If you want to see what condoms look like, search your parents' nightstands!" For some reason, not all parents found that funny.

You have fans in all sorts of places!  Over the weekend NPR was doing a story on summer reading, bringing on all sorts of book reviewers to talk about what people would/should be reading over the summer. The host asked one of the reviewers what he would like to read if he were able (apparently reviewers never get to read for enjoyment, all their reading time is spent on books to review), and the guy started talking about you and your books and how he'd love to read them if he had the time to! It made me grin.
It's nice to see a pageant winner with a brain. I can't believe only two finalists favored teaching evolution. I really get upset over that one.
Cameo role in season 2? :-)

Ms. Alabama was the only one I'm aware of that opposes (wrongly, in my view) teaching evolution. The other 47(?) contestants in question seemed to hold positions that stated that evolution should be taught in conjunction with other ideas.

Sadly, all of the contestants and most (even educated) people don't understand the issue. Religious folks think they have a problem with evolution, but they don't -- they have a problem with Naturalism (mostly: young earth creationists abuse the Hebrew text and torture it to confess to things that even Jews 3000 years ago didn't believe, so of course they have problems with evolution. And cosmology).

There is another group just as guilty of abusing the same text to the same extent, and it is those who attempt to use the 7-day creation poem in Genesis and other portions of the text to try and "prove" that science and religion (the usual target is Christianity) are incompatible.

The fact is that science is observation. We have observed change over time in existing species. But all should realize that evolution is a very nuanced idea, and that there are many components of it that are not understood, such as what mechanism drives it. Darwin's natural selection was a great idea for his time, but most biologists do not accept it as the sole driving force. Punctuated Equilibrium is a start, but many organisms have shown the ability to evolve exactly how they needed to exactly when they needed to, and this idea is just being explored within the last few years. Check out the book Quantum Evolution by JohnJoe McFadden if you would like to learn more about this absolutely fascinating aspect of biology.

On another note, ideas like BioLogos (championed by Francis Collins, one of the heads of the Human Genome Sequencing project), completely reconcile what is observed of our natural world with belief in a Creator (in Collins' case, the Christian God). He and those like him accomplish this by treating science as what it is (observation of our natural world) and treating their religious texts as what they are and were intended to be (in the case of Genesis, God's revelation to a pre-scientific Ancient Near Eastern culture).

In essence, the theory of evolution says nothing of how everything came to exist. Naturalism is the idea that everything is the result of natural processes, and that there is no Creator. That's the argument I wish these contestants had addressed, or understood. But it's hard to blame them when most people have the same blind spot.
comments.subject: Re: contestants on evolution

comments.article:
That's all very true, but it's beside the point. And to be fair, it's difficult for the public to keep up with this stuff. Punctuated Equilibrium is just starting to gain traction, so let's give it some time before we start decrying the public's ignorance of it. The REAL argument essentially boils down to science vs religion, and if creationism should be taught at all, be it alongside evolution or no.

Unfortunately, the Religious Right has made the PC way of posing this question to do so in the reverse: should EVOLUTION be taught in schools. That way the focus--and therefore, the burden of proof--is shifted away from creationism. It also allows zealots to sound fair and critical by hiding it behind phony arguments against evolution, rather than espousing Young-Earth thumpery. It also allows politicians to pander to the religious without alienating their centrist base.

What I do take issue with is that an attempt should be made to reconcile faith with science. They are natural enemies. Religion requires ignorance and obedience, and the blessed few who can maintain their faith while practicing such advanced science as the genome project do so by putting up blindspots of their own, because you CAN'T reconcile the two. Yeah, you can select certain passages that are vague enough to be taken as metaphor, but there's also a lot of things that are just flat wrong in these texts, and the only way to truly reconcile those items is to pretend they don't exist. Or allow for some other concession, such as the ever-popular "Well, it was written by men, after all," as if that doesn't render the whole book fallible.

No, Mr. Collins has not reconciled his faith with his science. He's carved a new faith out of his old one. And more power to him, but let's not pretend he's found the loophole.
comments.subject: Re: contestants on evolution

comments.article:
I love it when beauty and brains come together, go Miss America!

But as I see it, all that talk about teaching intelligent design or creationism as scientific theories (which they can never be as they are not scientifically provable) in school is just a ploy to get religion into education in a secularized country that...well, that plainly ISN'T secularized.

Just have religion as a subject in school and nobody will have to throw it in with science. We here in Germany have three subjects students from age 12 and up can choose from for themselves (younger students have to take what their parents tell them to) which are 'Catholic religion', 'Protestant religion' and 'Ethics' (for non-Christian students and those who want a more comparative approach). 'Islamic religion' has been in the talks for a while because of our large percentage of Islamic immigrants, but we don't have enough state-certified Islam teachers yet.

Secularization is neat, me being an atheist and all, but it can and does bear the most rotten of fruits when a society is not ready for it. Give the Christian lobby in the US not what they WANT (pseudo-scientific blabber in science classes), but what they NEED (the option to teach religion as an independent subject in all school forms and years).
comments.subject: Re: contestants on evolution

comments.article: Striking a blow for geeks everywhere!

It seems that copies of Dance have in fact been leaked and there are spoilers being spilled everywhere. Similar to the Harry Potter: Deathly Hallows spoiling issue, it seems people are getting off on spoiling the book. I've so far heard of 4Chan, several gaming forums, Reddit, and even the Giants official forums. There are Twitter bots sending out ADWD spoilers as well.

Just FYI. Myself, I'm quitting most of the internet for the next few days.
comments.subject: Just a warning for fellow fans

comments.article: You're damn right we're smarter! ROCK ON EVOLUTION!

Mellisandre candidate for season 2?

I watched all agonizingly long 14 minutes of the "Should evolution be taught?" video, and there were more than two with a reasonable answer- a still depressing 4-5, but I was impressed by Miss Vermont's. What was super distressing was the number of contestants who were like "Yes... because BOTH sides should be taught! ^__^" False dichotomy implying that there *are* sides about a scientific law. :/

Precisely.

If we are going to teach "both sides" of evolution, then schools should give equal time to the flat-earthers as well.

It is the theory of evolution, not law. I don't believe a theory should be taught as fact. I think it should be represented in a public school as is. A theory. The 2nd law of thermodynamics (correct me if I am wrong, I have no problems learning or debating civilized) refutes evolution to my understanding. And as a law I believe it should be taught as such. None can prove the existence of God so it can be considered just as theoretical as evolution. I'm not trying to push one over the other.....just sayin

Yeah, it really is possible. Right now I´m holding
a dance with dragons in my hands. I´m from Germany it seems they are shipping way earlier than thought.
Excited now... off reading.
comments.subject: a dance with dragon
